If you don't want to admit it's the best motocross simulation out there, you can at least concede it's the closest we'll get to a three dimensional cross-over of Trials HD and QWOP.

It's less of a game than it is a physics toy box. There are some rudimentary tracks and bikes available, but the community more than makes up for it as well as the lack of offline bot opponents. The bike packs at mxb-mods.com are a must for online play.

I've recently, at just over 90 hours, tried MX Bikes on a WMR headset and it is an amazing experience as of February 2024. Yes, a keyboard and mouse is necessary through all of the flat menus and gameplay is performed with the same ol' XB1S controller, but the immersion is deliriously fun. Tweaking the POV pitch and tilt to around half really encourages a naturalistic head turn into turns and up or down hills. It's such an improvement to situational awareness that it is simply the way this physics toy is to be experienced.

If you're a fan of motocross or racing games, MX Bikes offers a thrilling and immersive experience that's worth considering. Here's why you should give it a try:

Realistic Simulation: MX Bikes provides one of the most realistic simulations of motocross racing available in the gaming world. From bike physics to terrain deformation, every aspect is meticulously crafted to offer an authentic experience.

Thrilling Gameplay: Experience the adrenaline rush of motocross racing as you navigate through challenging tracks, perform stunts, and compete against skilled opponents. The dynamic gameplay ensures every race is exciting and unpredictable.

Extensive Customization: Customize your bike and rider to suit your preferences and racing style. From tweaking bike settings to choosing gear and liveries, MX Bikes offers a high level of customization to make your experience unique.

Online Multiplayer: Compete against friends or players from around the world in online multiplayer modes. Test your skills against real opponents and climb the leaderboards to prove your dominance on the track.

Active Community and Modding Support: Join a vibrant community of players and modders who continually contribute new content, tracks, bikes, and features to enhance the game. With modding support, the possibilities are endless, ensuring a fresh experience every time you play.

Whether you're a seasoned motocross enthusiast or simply looking for an exhilarating racing experience, MX Bikes offers hours of entertainment and excitement that's sure to keep you coming back for more.

I've always been a roadracing fan so coming from games like Ride & MotoGp to this after not having played a motocross game since the old MX VS ATV days it was a steep learning curve just to get the hang of the physics. However once I got my settings right, downloaded the OEM mod and got on a 2-stroke i realized why i wanted this game. Ripping on a 2-stroke can't help but leave anyone smiling, just need some Stankdog 726 graphics and ill be set.

If anyone gets this game you will want to go to https://mxb-mods.com because it just has many extra bikes and rider gear. The default Steam Install just doesn't have them and this game has a vary nice official Discord for us players to find people to interact with when you want, right here at: https://discord.gg/mx-bikes
 
This game is a must have for PC users because it has endless amount of updated tracks people are creating, and site has extra bike patches giving you 30 or more extra Bike's to download and site has extra Rider and bike color and design gear. 

The Controller settings, I can't get over how much extra settings this game has!. You can slow up or speed up your sensitivity controls to your liking, you will never see any game having these amount of sensitive settings that make this game a dream come true to have!. 

If you ever plan to play in 3rd person view you will wanna slow down your Direct lean and have under your advanced controls, under the Advanced Lean to enable the Smooth Press and if you play in 1st person you will have your Direct Lean Higher and Lean Smooth press off. If you find your self lifting the bike front wheel into a crash too much just go to your settings and Under Advanced Throttle settings and Enable the throttle Smooth Press and set it much higher to help you keep the front bike wheel down as you throttle and it can help keep the bike stable to you learn to get faster, and make sure to Sit down on the bike for the corners and when you ride off the jumps sit sometimes, and make sure to stand on the bike just before you land or you will bounce your bike into a crash.

Here is a good tip...make sure when you play around with your throttle trigger settings on your controller by pressing your Right analog trigger up and down to help you find the right adjustment settings to use while you are setting up your throttle sensitivity under (Advanced Throttle, Linearity and Smooth Press, adjustment settings, and your Lean Linearity settings is best at 150% and Lean Gain settings at least 88% or a little higher but not too low or can't make them corners or making it too high or you will fall over when you corner while making them turns often. 
This game will not work right if you use keyboard because you need the sensitive analog throttle triggers and the Left thumb stick on the controllers has sensitive lean stick controls, no keyboard that I know of has this.

This game also has an incredibly passionate community, and essentially this game is a template for modders/track builders to create whatever they want. 

Only complaint is that the physics can be goofy at times. If you land flat off a big jump/overjump, you are going to bounce to the sky box. Now, the new OEM bikes have attempted to fix this issue, but they can only do so much. Same with going up hills in this game. While the community has done a great job limiting the goofier physics aspects of this game, PiBoSo still needs to make an effort to fix these issues. Game has a lot of potential and this is the main thing holding it back imo. Regardless, easy recommend to anyone that loves dirt bikes/loved the old MX vs ATV games.

MX Bikes is not just a game; it's a revelation in the world of virtual motorcycle simulations. This digital masterpiece, crafted with an unwavering commitment to realism and unparalleled attention to detail, redefines the very essence of off-road biking experiences.

Graphics That Set New Standards (5/5):
From the moment you twist the throttle, MX Bikes thrusts you into a visually stunning world. The meticulously crafted graphics are nothing short of breathtaking. Every inch of the meticulously designed bike models and intricately detailed terrains evoke an authentic sense of being on the track. Dynamic weather effects add another layer of realism, making each race a sensory delight.

Gameplay Mastery (5/5):
MX Bikes redefines the concept of motorcycle simulation. It doesn't just simulate the act of riding; it replicates the art of mastering a two-wheeled beast. The physics engine, a work of genius, ensures that every twist of the throttle, every weight shift, and every jump demand your skill and precision. Success in MX Bikes is not handed to you; it's earned through hard-earned mastery of your virtual machine. Controls are intuitively responsive, whether you're using a gamepad or a high-end racing wheel.

A World of Possibilities (4.5/5):
The game's content is as diverse as the terrains you'll ride on. MX Bikes offers a generous selection of tracks and bikes, but the true richness lies in its passionate modding community. A universe of user-created content, including tracks, bikes, and customization options, extends the game's longevity and keeps every race fresh and exciting.

Multiplayer Magic (4/5):
Competing against real players in MX Bikes takes the thrill to a whole new level. The multiplayer aspect is a heart-pounding experience, where your skills are put to the test against riders from around the world. However, a slightly less populous multiplayer scene might result in longer wait times between races, but it's a minor quibble in the grand scheme of this exceptional game.

Unmatched Realism (5/5):
What sets MX Bikes leagues apart from the competition is its relentless pursuit of realism. The physics simulation is an engineering marvel, capturing the nuances of real-world biking with astonishing accuracy. Every aspect, from tire wear to suspension tuning, and bike setup, mirrors the intricacies of real motocross. MX Bikes is not just a game; it's a simulator that blurs the lines between the digital realm and the mud-spattered, heart-pounding world of off-road racing.

Conclusion:
MX Bikes isn't just a game; it's an immersion into the heart-pounding world of off-road motorcycle racing. Its awe-inspiring graphics, precise gameplay, rich content offerings, and an unwavering commitment to realism make it a standout in the genre. While the multiplayer scene might benefit from more participants, it's the single-player experience, the vibrant modding community, and the level of detail that propel MX Bikes into a league of its own. If you're a motorcycle racing enthusiast seeking an authentic, heart-thumping experience, MX Bikes is your ticket to a world where the line between virtual and reality blurs into oblivion. This game is a work of art, a true masterpiece of two-wheeled artistry.

The control system is intuitive and responsive, making it easy and enjoyable to learn the game. The developers have clearly put a lot of time and effort into achieving the realistic sensation of motorcycling, and it shows in the quality of the game.

What sets mxBikes apart even further is how incredibly easy it is to set up mods, including new motorcycles and maps. The ability to customize and enhance the game with user-created content adds a whole new layer of excitement and keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The modding community for mxBikes is vibrant and supportive, making it a breeze to find and install new content, enhancing the game's replayability immensely.

I can't recommend this game. Ive played it for 40 hours or so, and here are my takes:
Pros
- Modding community
- track selection
- game doesn't crash
- Can be addictive in the right conditions
Cons
- Modding Community
- Terrible Physics
- Absolutely no way to tell what is actually causing you to crash
- People with 1000+ hours will complain about "Piboso things" in relation to weird physics
- Game isn't complete and probably won't ever be complete
- Only has testing and online racing with people who will wreck you and the netcode is terrible

To elaborate, the game has the real sense that it could be great. At first you will play it and realize that its very hard and that you need to practice to get better. The online community will tell you that you need 50 hours in order to make a few laps without crashing. The problem is, this never really gets better. Sure you will get more consistent and crash less, but the random crashes and weird slow/uphill physics, and the bad suspension  no matter what bike mod you use, WILL and I mean WILL ruin races and ruin your fun. The problem is there is too much going on. You have to control the bike steering as well as leaning (and this is normal in motorcross games) however in this one if you don't have them aligned just perfectly you will crash. CONSTANTLY! And the problem is, there is nothing really to show you or help you "feel" when you are about to crash. You have to do it based on visual position of your helmet, and hundres and hundres of hours to be able to generally "memorize" how to do everything. Thats not fun. Its terribly annoying. It will make you want to punch a wall. They tried to make a pure simulation, but the problems are too complex to solve well with a controller and no other ways to tell what is going on. At least in sim racing we have FFB, you dont get that in MX Bikes. The game will probalby never be out of a beta state, and the modding community (though great) is a pain to work with. Loading files, updating files, all to find out that the bikes still have the same underlying problems because its how the physics work. Piboso should imo have found a better balance between sim and game where you could actually control the bikes and better riders would have better lap times, but not going as far as they did. The way the made the game, 90% of people who try it will uninstall it after a week...Its that inconsistent and difficult in all the wrong ways...

This is hands down one of the best, if not the best motocross simulator. When you buy the game you only get the stock PiBoSo bikes, and tracks. However, we have a HUGE mod community that keeps this game fresh, and fun to play. The OEM guys release new OEM bikes year in and year out, while many others make great tracks for us all to play. There is also a huge racing scene, with many series from fun races, to full blown pro series with dedicated members of this community making tracks, live streaming, and prize pools. If you enjoy riding IRL, or just want to have fun on a dirt bike, I highly recommend you get this game. It will be frustrating at first, but if you put in the time, you will get better, and have loads of fun. Aside from MX & SX, there is also a enduro scene, with OEM bikes, IRL tracks, and much more. Almost 80% of the mods for the game are free, but if you want to support creators, and get exclusive bikes and tracks, you can do so.  I will recommend that you have a decent amount of storage as all the mods do start to take up space. Other than that, I hope this review is helpful, and you decide to buy the game.

Yes, I have invested 7 hours in MX Bikes already, and while it might seem premature to write a review, I believe sharing my experience can benefit new players and provide some useful tips. Let's dive in.

Price: Initially, I found the AUD $49 price tag hard to justify, and I contemplated whether the game was worth it. In my opinion, the game should be priced around $30. However, I can say with certainty that regardless of the cost, MX Bikes is undeniably a worthwhile investment. It has earned its reputation as the GMOD of its genre, offering a plethora of fresh, community-made content such as bikes, gear, and tracks. Even the base game, with its included bikes and tracks, provides a solid 10 hours of exploration and a true taste of the game.

Physics: The physics in MX Bikes are nothing short of incredible. Playing in the first-person perspective, which is the preferred choice for most players, delivers an immersive experience like no other essentially 1:1 like on a real bike. However, I did notice that the third-person perspective makes the rider appear stiff, and the overall game-play feels somewhat heavy and unnatural (a personal preference). But fear not, as the satisfaction of flawlessly greasing through set of whoops compensates for any shortcomings.

Settings: It is important to note that the initial settings in MX Bikes may not be the most beginner-friendly. When I first loaded the game, I immediately looked into the settings because I struggled to even start the bike. I recommend taking the time to tweak the automated settings, such as clutch, ABS, rider lean, and sitting position. YouTube can be your best friend here, as it provides valuable insights from experienced players and helps you establish a starting point for your own preferences. Experimentation is key, yet don't hesitate to draw inspiration from professional players' settings.

Comparison: I must stress that MX Bikes is not MX Sim, and I made the mistake of assuming they were similar. However, this turned out to be one of the best mistakes I've made (excluding my son). MX Bikes stands tall in its own right, offering an exceptional gaming experience that deserves recognition.

Conclusion: I wholeheartedly recommend purchasing MX Bikes, and if it doesn't meet your expectations, you always have the option to refund. Keep in mind that the game is still in early access, but that shouldn't deter you from giving this awesome game a chance. The overall feel, physics, variety of bikes and tracks, and the vibrant community are all aspects that make MX Bikes truly awesome. Give it a few hours, find your groove, and you'll walk away with an 500 litres of dopamine in your system.

When you hear about simulators, obviously you hear "MX Sim", but you also hear "MX Bikes". Known for being an easier sim game to get into than MX Sim and with a modding community just as good. Pros:
1 Very realistic physics (most the time)
2 Very versatile modding community
3 Decently optimized for low end devices (what I own myself)
Cons:
1 Bad low speed physics most the time
2 "Piboso Physics Moment" quite frequently happening (ex: casing a jump and doing 3 backflips)
3 Game updates that break all mods. These updates normally are to make the stock Piboso bikes ride better, but everyone uses the OEM bikes so its just unnecessary updates.
Overall, such a great game that I forget its in early access still.

Mx Bikes is an exhilarating motocross game that offers an authentic and immersive two-wheeled racing experience. Developed by PiBoSo, this simulation-based game takes you on a thrilling ride through challenging tracks, realistic physics, and an extensive customization system.

One of the standout features of Mx Bikes is its attention to detail when it comes to physics and bike handling. The game captures the essence of motocross racing with its realistic bike dynamics, including weight shifting, suspension behavior, and tire grip. The controls are responsive and intuitive, allowing you to feel the adrenaline rush as you navigate through jumps, corners, and rough terrain.

The track selection in Mx Bikes is impressive, offering a variety of environments such as outdoor motocross tracks, supercross arenas, and even off-road trails. Each track is meticulously designed with attention to detail, providing a sense of realism and challenge.
